div1.p: [Carter] obtains two rare books and needs Frost to finalize those references so that she can return the books.

div1.head: Memorandum from [Laura Armistead Carter] to Wade Hampton Frost, June 20, 1930 [Enclosed in C0328019]
div1.p:
Went to the Library of the S. G. of the Army yesterday and got out
(a) Linde (1792) and (b) Schotte (1782). As you know, these books are very
essential to part of the argument in Section iii, part 2 (Africa).

The Assistant Librarian, Mr. Tupper, was most unwilling to have them
leave the Library and only allowed it, on my reminding him that Colonel
Ashburn had allowed me to do so on several other occasions. He states,
however, that this is the last time that they can be taken out so I hope
that you will be ready to check the respective cards for the above authors
when I go over next week. I suggested to Mr. Tupper that the Welch Library
might get them for you to see, as a loan, but he says that they are too
rare and too frail to risk in the mail, and I had tom promise that I would not mail them to anyone, which, by
the way, was what I was intending to do (by registered mail, of course, and
most carefully packed as well as wrapped)

Doubtless you can get these books yourself later, over Mr. Tuppers
head, but this is certainly the last time that I can get them out.

I don't want to get Mr. Tupper into any trouble, so have made this
a separate Mem., so that you can destroy it after reading. He is a very
nervous man, near retiring age, and, of course, it would be a calamity to
him if the books were injured or lost. Equally of course, it is essential
that you see them and read part of them en bloc as some of the text [unclear] of
the MS referring to them will need to be made much clearer by yourself or
else mislead the average reader.
